abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about public
            works and grants to create safety net in Ethiopia. For a
            quarter-century, images of severe drought and widespread
            starvation have become relentlessly linked with Ethiopia.
            Each day, they manage hunger, extreme hardship, and multiple
            sources of uncertainty. Most vulnerable households work as
            subsistence farmers on small plots of degraded land, and are
            subject to the vicissitudes of weather. International
            Development Association (IDA) financed Productive Safety Net
            Program (PSNP) which launched in 2005 to help the country
            shift from an emergency relief system to a more effective
            development-oriented safety net. Up to 192 million paid
            workdays have been generated through community projects that
            addressed some of the roots of food insecurity by
            rehabilitating severely degraded land and creating
            productive community assets such as terraced fields, feeder
            roads, and small-scale irrigation systems. Ethiopia faced a
            potentially devastating crisis from a vicious circle of
            drought, food shortages and high food prices. An estimated
            12 million people were affected. The project drew on the
            Bank's global experience in safety net design and
            collaborated with the government in adapting insights to the
            Ethiopian context. The project played a vital role in
            warding off famine in 2008. As a result food security
            improved among participating households, as measured by
            self-reported caloric intake. Agricultural productivity
            increased, community water supplies were improved and family
            health benefited. The government of Ethiopia provided
            in-kind contributions through program supervision and
            management support.
